fields.name: Interacting with own personal health and care record
Updating individual health record from various data sources (including mobiles devices, wearables)
Transferring information when service users and care providers are separated in time and/or space
Enabling participation in prevention and health coaching initiatives, receiving feedback and peer-support
Enabling service users to manage and utilise a personal health budget
Enabling service users to access tools (e.g. appointment booking and reminders, ordering prescriptions etc.)
Enabling service users to consume personalised health education information
Providing personalised health education materials for individual service users
Enabling care professionals to interact (read/write) with organisational electronic care record system, as part of direct care delivery
Enabling care professinals to interact (read) with Shared Care Record, as part of direct care delivery
Enabling care professionals to utilise real-time clinical decision support tools to provide care to service users
Enabling transfer of information to care professionals in other providers as part of transfer of care
Enrolling individuals into prevention and health coaching initiatives and providing feedback
Systematically selecting impactible individuals within risk-stratified population cohorts for early intervention or prevention
Managing customised care plans for individuals
Managing care professional caseload within and across provider organisations
Identifying risk strata within service user flows
Optimising service user flow, managing , demand, risk strata and service capacity, within and across providers
Tailoring personal care approaches based on genetic, environmental, and lifestyle factors
Allocating risk scores and stratifying populations for specified future adverse events causing poor health outcomes to individuals
Identifying individuals and groups within risk-stratified cohorts on which interventions will have the greatest impact
Managing quality of health and care services (including clinical audit)
Monitoring and evaluating effectiveness of care co-ordination processes
Monitoring and evaluating effectiveness of citizen-activation/empowerment processes
Monitoring service utilisation, pathway compliance, citizen experience and outcomes
Supporting budget planning, management and reporting
Monitoring activity and cost compliance against contract and agreed plans
Comparing provider quality, demand, experience and service user outcomes against contract and agreed plans
Comparing performance and managing variation across care professionals, services, providers, systems
Ensuring compliance with evidence and guidance
Maximising services and outcomes within financial envelopes within and across providers
Supporting benchmarking, comparisons, regulation and assurance at all levels of the health and care system
Reviewing, evaluating and transforming current health and care service provision across and within populations
Understanding how health and care services impact on the health of populations
Understanding the impact of wider determinants of health on populations

Defining and identifying relevant segments and cohorts within populations driving cost, utilisation and quality challenges including: health inequality groups, preventable and existing conditions and gaps in care
Comparing population groups, peers, national and international best practice
Designing and evaluating effective risk stratification approaches
Identifying future population needs, spend, growth and drivers for change
Combining primary and secondary data in research studies/clinical trials
General provision of population health management
fields.duty_of_confidence: Implied consent/reasonable expectations or pseudo/anon data where it doesn't apply

fields.name: Co-ordinating and optimising service user flows
Risk stratification for early intervention and prevention
Planning, implementing and evaluating population health strategy
General provision of population health management (including direct care, secondary uses and 'hybrid' activities)
Secondary data use activities
fields.description: Where data is used for purposes other than the individual care of thepatient. Includes activities that contribute to the overall provisionof services to a population as a whole or a group of patients witha particular condition.

fields.name: Individual care
fields.description: A clinical, social or public health activity concerned with theprevention, investigation and treatment of illness and thealleviation of suffering of individuals.

fields.name: Earlier identification of patients on disease pathways (e.g. cancer diagnosis)
Increase in attainment of individual health goals (e.g. quitting smoking, increased levels of exercise, healthier diet)
Reduction in health related unemployment and work absence
Reduction in incidence of preventable diseases
Increase in cooperation between NHS services and the voluntary sector
Increase in patients accessing specialist advice where their disease pathway requires specialist support.
Reduction in inappropriate admissions to hospitals
Increase in patients receiving case management
Increase in local understanding of where variation in the use of services occurs
Increase in patient education and awareness relating to the management of their care
Increase in the activation of patients in the management of their individual healthcare
Increase in democratic leadership on public health
Increase in volunteers from local communities
Reduction in cost of a treatment
Reduction in costly treatments arising from prevented illness
Reduction in management and administration costs
Increase in staff satisfaction, recruitment and retention
Mental health, dementia and learning disabilities
Community and out of hospital care
Wider determinents to support population health
Electronic patient records data (acute and urgent care)
fields.example_data_sets: EPR (wider patient-level data set captured in providers with EPRs)

fields.name: Commissioning data sets (A&E, admitted patient care, outpatients)
fields.example_data_sets: SUS(SEM), SUS(PbR), HES, local daily acute data

fields.name: Critical care
fields.example_data_sets: Neonatal critical care MDS, paediatric critical care MDS

fields.name: Emergency ambulance
fields.example_data_sets: Conformed local emergency ambulance data set

fields.name: Contract monitoring (acute and urgent care)
fields.example_data_sets: Patient level contract monitoring (acute and urgent care)

fields.name: Best practice tariffs
fields.example_data_sets: Best practice tariff monitoring data sets

fields.name: Electronic patient records data (mental health)
fields.example_data_sets: EPR (wider patient-level data set captured in providers with EPRs)

fields.name: GP
fields.example_data_sets: GP data set, GP activity volumes, GPES

fields.name: Electronic patient records data (community)
fields.example_data_sets: EPR (wider patient-level data set captured in providers with EPRs)

fields.name: Voluntary sector health and care services
Care and nursing homes
fields.example_data_sets: Local care and nursing home data sets

fields.name: Child health
fields.example_data_sets: Childhood obesity central return, national child measurement programme (NCMP)

fields.name: Alcohol, drug and substance misuse
fields.example_data_sets: Local alcohol, drug and substance misuse data

fields.name: Screening
fields.example_data_sets: Breast screening programme data set, local cervical screening data, local bowel screening data

fields.name: Sexual health
fields.example_data_sets: HARS, SRHAD, GUMCAD, CTAD, local sexual health data, health and justice SARCs

fields.name: Smoking cessation
fields.example_data_sets: NHS stop smoking services quarterly monitoring return

fields.name: Cancer
fields.example_data_sets: Cancer waiting times, national bowel cancer audit, local cancer data

fields.name: Infectious diseases
fields.example_data_sets: Health protection data sets, local infectious diseases data

fields.name: Public health and justice
fields.example_data_sets: Local public health and justice data sets

fields.name: Specialised services
fields.example_data_sets: Cataract data set, Badgernet, UK cystic fibrosis registry, national hip fracture database, GUMCAD, IVIG, radiotherapy data set, UKROC, national renal data set (UKRR), spinal cord injury data set, TARN

fields.name: Non-specialised services
fields.example_data_sets: Diabetic retinopathy screening data set, VTE risk assessment data collection

fields.name: Diagnostic imaging
fields.example_data_sets: DIDS, diagnostics waiting times and activity data collection

fields.name: Prescribing
fields.example_data_sets: EPS, ePACT, prescribing volumes, secondary care prescribing data

fields.name: Waiting lists
fields.example_data_sets: Elective admissions list, end of period census & events during period CDS types, direct access audiology priority treatment list (PTL), RTT PTLs

fields.name: Patient safety
fields.example_data_sets: Surveillance of healthcare associated infections, assuring transformation

fields.name: Social care workforce
fields.example_data_sets: Local social care workforce data sets

fields.name: Environmental
fields.example_data_sets: Local pollution monitoring data, local environmental data

fields.name: Survey
fields.example_data_sets: Health survey for england, understanding society, national diet & nutrition survey, household for England survey, active lines survey

fields.name: DUTY: To provide services for rare and very rare conditions
DUTY: To provide primary medical services
DUTY: To exercise relevant public health functions
DUTY: To provide health service for prisoners
DUTY: To provide health services to the armed forces
DUTY: To provide community dental services
DUTY: To provide high secure  psychiatric services
DUTY: To provide primary ophthalmic services
DUTY:  To provide mental health after care services
DUTY:  To assess the performance of CCGs
DUTY: Assessment and provisions of NHS continuing healthcare
DUTY: To commission hospital accommodation, medical, ophthalmic, nursing and ambulance service
DUTY:   Co-operation with social services regarding the provision of NHS continuing healthcare
DUTY: Improving quality of primary medical services
DUTY: Provide services to improve public health
DUTY:  To provide dental public health services
DUTY: To co-operate with CCGs and NHS England
DUTY (NHS Trust Only): Provision of NHS goods and services
DUTY (NHS FT Only): Delivery of NHS goods and services
Duty: To promote a comprehensive health service
fields.details:
Duty to promote a comprehensive health service, designed to secure the improvement in the physical and mental health of people in England and the prevention, diagnoses and treatment of illness.

NHS England is subject to this duty alongside the Secretary of State, except for that part of the health service that is delivered in pursuit of public health functions of the Secretary of State or local authorities. 
(NHS Act 2006, S1H(2))

fields.name: Power: To do anything that will facilitate the discharge of functions under the 2006 Act
fields.details:
NHS England has the power to do anything calculated to facilitate, or is conducive or incidental to the discharge of any function given to NHS England under the 2006 Act.

This includes, for example, the carrying out of counter-fraud/ security measures.

(NHS Act 2006, section 2, NHS Act 2006, section 195(2) regarding counter-fraud/ security measures)

fields.name: Duty: To provide high secure  psychiatric services
fields.details:
NHS England has a duty to provide secure psychiatric premises for people who are liable to be detained under the Mental Health Act 1983 and need treating in a high security environment.
(NHS Act 2006, S4, HSCA 2012, S16)

fields.name: Power: Performance of functions outside England
fields.details:
NHS England can arrange for services to be provided outside of England if this relates to:

* holidays for patients
* the transfer of patients to or from Scotland, Northern Ireland, the Isle of Man or the Channel Islands, or
* the return of patients who have received treatment in England and Wales, to countries or territories outside the British Islands (including for this purpose the Republic of Ireland). 

 (NHS Act 2006 s6)

fields.name: Duty: To exercise relevant public health functions
fields.details:
The Secretary of State for Health can require NHS England to carry out some of his public health tasks.  The Secretary of State’s requirements are set out annually in the Public Health Functions Agreement.

More detail on what public health functions NHS England carries out under the agreement can be found here:
https://www.england.nhs.uk/commissioning/pub-hlth-res/

(NHS Act 2006 , section 7A)

fields.name: Power: To assist SoS in providing health services and exercising public health functions
fields.details:
SSection 12 empowers the Secretary of State to make arrangements with any person or body to provide, or assist in providing, anything that the Secretary of State has a duty or power to provide, or arrange for the provision of, under section 2A or 2B or Schedule 1 of the 2006 Act, as amended (the Secretary of State’s duty as to the protection of public health and the improvement of public health respectively).

(NHS Act 2006, S12, HSCA 2012, s22)

fields.name: Power: To make direct payments to patients
fields.details:
NHS England can secure the delivery of services to a patient by making a direct payment to the patient/ their nominee for the services.  NHS England can work with other organisations to deliver direct payments, including voluntary organisations.

Further detail is set out in regulations.

(NHS Act 2006, section 12A
National Health Service (Direct Payments) Regulations 2013)

fields.name: Duty: To exercise functions efficiently
fields.details:
NHS England must exercise its functions effectively, efficiently and economically.
(NHS Act 2006, s13D)

fields.name: Duty: To secure continuous improvement in the quality of services
fields.details:
Duty on NHS England to exercise its functions with a view to securing continuous improvement in the quality of health and public health services provided to individuals.
(NHS Act 2006, S13E, HSCA 2012 S23)

fields.name: Duty: To reduce health inequalities
fields.details:
When carrying out its functions NHS England must have regard to the need to:

* reduce inequalities in relation to accessing health services
* reduce inequalities between patients that relate to the provision of healthcare services
(NHS Act 2006, section 13G)

fields.name: Duty: To promote integrated health services
fields.details:
NHS England has a duty to exercise its functions with a view to ensuring that health services are provided in an integrated way where this would:

* improve quality of health services (including outcomes) or
* reduce inequalities of access to health services or
* reduce inequalities of outcomes achieved by health services

(NHS Act 2006, s13N(1))

fields.name: Duty: To promote integration between health services and health-related services
fields.details:
NHS England has a duty to exercise its functions with a view to ensuring that health services are integrated with the provision of health-related services and social care services where this would: 

* improve quality of health services (including outcomes) or
* reduce inequalities of access to health services or
* reduce inequalities of outcomes achieved by health services

“Health-related services” includes any service that has an effect on the health of individuals but that is not a health or social care service e.g. housing.

(NHS Act 2006, s13N(2))

fields.name: Duty: to encourage the use of section 75 agreements between CCGs and local authorities
fields.details:
NHS England must also encourage CCGs to enter into arrangements with local authorities for the delivery of health services (section 75 agreements) where it considers that this would secure:

* the better integration of health services; or
* the better integration of health services with health-related services

And:

* improve quality of health services (including outcomes) or
* reduce inequalities of access to health services or
* reduce inequalities of outcomes achieved by health services

(NHS Act 2006, section 13N(3))

fields.name: Power: To generate income
fields.details:
NHS England has the power to raise additional income in some circumstances, provided this does not interfere to a significant extent with the performance by NHS England of its functions.

NHS England can raise extra income through:

* acquiring, producing, manufacturing or supplying goods
* acquiring land by agreement and management of the land
* providing instructions to any person
* developing and exploiting with intellectual property
* an appropriate action which will facilitate one of the above
* making appropriate charges relating to any such power as listed above.

(NHS Act 2006, s13W)

fields.name: Duty: Enabling patient choice
fields.details:
NHS England must act with a view to enabling patients to make choices with respect to aspects of health services provided to them.
(NHS Act 2006, section 13I)

fields.name: Duty: To promote innovation
fields.details:
NHS England must promote innovation in the provision of health services, including innovative approaches to commissioning.
(NHS Act 2006, s13K)

fields.name: Duty: To promote research
fields.details:
NHS England must promote research relevant to the health service and the use of such research in the health service.
(NHS Act 2006, s13L)

fields.name: Duty: Understand impact of commissioning decisions on provision of services to Welsh and Scottish residents
fields.details: NHS England must have regard to the likely impact of its commissioning decisions on the provision of health services to people who live in an area of Wales or Scotland that is close to the border with England.  (NHS Act 2006 s13O, s23  HSCA 2012)

fields.name: Duty: Public and patient involvement
fields.details:
NHS England must involve the public and the patients in decisions including:

* the planning of commissioning arrangements
* decisions made that affect the manner services are delivered or the range of services provided

(NHS Act 2006, s13Q)

fields.name: Duty: To collect and analyse information relating to safety of services
fields.details:
NHS England may:

* Establish and operate systems for collecting and analysing information relating to the safety of the services provided by the health service.  Such information and analyses of it must be made available to other appropriate persons.
* Give advice and guidance, to such persons as it considers appropriate, for the purpose of maintaining and improving the safety of the services provided by the health service and monitor the effectiveness of the advice and guidance.

(NHS Act 2006, S13R, HSCA 2012, s23)

fields.name: Power: To provide assistance and support to CCGs
fields.details:
NHS England may provide assistance or support to a CCG.  This can include the provision of information.
(NHS Act 2006, s14Z1)

fields.name: Duty: Issue guidance on commissioning to CCGs
fields.details:
NHS England must publish guidance for CCGs on the discharge of their commissioning functions.
(NHS Act 2006, section 14Z8)

fields.name: Duty: To assess the performance of CCGs
fields.details:
Each year NHS England must assess the performance of each CCG.
(NHS Act 2006, section 14Z16)

fields.name: Duty: To provide primary medical services
fields.details:
NHS England must secure the provision of primary medical services.
(NHS Act 2006, S83(1), HSCA 2012, Sched 4, p30)

fields.name: Duty: To provide primary ophthalmic services
fields.details:
NHS England must secure the provision of primary ophthalmic services, in accordance with detailed regulations.  This includes sight-testing.
(NHS Act 2007, S115)

fields.name: Duty: To provide pharmaceutical services
fields.details:
NHS England must make arrangements for the provision of pharmaceutical services, in accordance with various regulations.
(Schedule 4, paragraph 63, HSCA 2012). (NHS Act 2009, S126)

fields.name: Power: To supply local authorities with goods, services and facilities
fields.details:
NHS England has the power to supply to local authorities (and such public bodies as the Secretary of State may determine) any goods or materials of a kind used in the health service.

It also has a power to make available to local authorities any facilities the provision of which is arranged by NHS England, any facilities of NHS England, and the services of persons employed by NHS England (e.g. secondments).

NHS England can also arrange for the carrying out of maintenance work in connection with any land or building for the maintenance of which a local authority is responsible.

(NHS Act 2006, s80)

fields.name: Duty: To pay CCGs to meet their expenditure
fields.details:
Section 223G requires NHS England to make a contribution in each financial year to each CCG.
(NHS Act 2006, S223G, HSCA 2012, S27)

fields.name: Power: Integration funding
fields.details:
NHS England can require that CCGs put some of their funding into a pooled fund to spend on integration, and attach conditions to that funding.
(NHS Act 2006, s223GA)

fields.name: Power: To make payments to CCGs in respect of quality of services
fields.details:
Under section 223K, the NHSCB has the ability, after the end of a financial year, to make a payment to a CCG in respect of quality. Section 223K(2) specifies that at least one of the prescribed factors must be taken into account by the NHSCB when determining whether to make a payment under section 223K. These factors include:

* The quality of relevant services provided;
* Any improvement in quality in comparison to the previous financial years;
* Achievement of outcomes identified for the financial year.

NHS England has the ability, after the end of a financial year, to make a payment to a CCG in respect of quality. At least one of the following factors must be taken into account by the NHS England:

* The quality of relevant services provided
* Any improvement in quality in comparison to the previous financial years
* Outcomes for the financial year.

NHS England may also take into account either or both of the following factors:

* Relevant inequalities identified during the financial year
* Any reduction in relevant inequalities identified during that year in comparison to those identified during the previous financial years.

(NHS Act 2006, section 223K National Health Service (Clinical Commissioning Groups – Payments in Respect of Quality) Regulations 2013, SI 2013/474)

fields.name: Power: To make a contribution to local authority costs
fields.details:
NHS England can make payments to local authorities towards the costs incurred by local authorities regarding particular social services and housing functions.
(NHS Act 2006, section 256)

fields.name: Power: To conduct research
fields.details:
NHS England may conduct, commission or assist the conduct of research into:

* any matters relating to the causation, prevention, diagnosis or treatment of illness; and
* any other matters connected with the health service that NHS England considers appropriate.

(NHS Act 2006, Sched 1 p13)

fields.name: Power: To obtain and analyse data
fields.details:
NHS England can obtain and analyse data or other information for any purpose connected with the exercise of its functions in relation to the health service
(NHS Act 2006, Schedule 1, paragraph 13(3))

fields.name: Duty: To co-operate with NHS bodies when delivering care functions
fields.details:
A NHS England  must co-operate with local authorities and vice versa, when providing care services to adults, support services to carers and other related services
(Care Act 2014, section 6)

fields.name: Duty: To work with local authorities to improve the well-being of young children
fields.details:
NHS England has a duty to work with the local authority in connection with the authority’s arrangements for improving well-being etc. of young children.
(Children Act 2006, s4)

fields.name: Duty: To help local authorities support children and families
fields.details:
NHS England has a duty to comply with any request from a local authority to help exercise any of its functions relating to support for children and families if compatible with the CCG’s own functions.
(Children Act 1989, s27)

fields.name: Duty: To make arrangements for safeguarding and promoting the welfare of children
fields.details: Duty for NHS England to make arrangements to ensure that when carrying out its functions regard is had to the need to safeguard and promote the welfare of children. (Children Act 2004 s11)

fields.name: Duty: Eliminate discrimination, harassment and victimisation and advance equality of opportunity
fields.details:
Duty for NHS England to have due regard to the need to:

* eliminate unlawful discrimination, harassment and victimisation
* advance equality of opportunity between persons who share a relevant “protected characteristic” (e.g. ethnicity, gender) and persons who do not and
* foster good relations between persons who share a relevant protected characteristic and persons who do not.

(Equalities Act 2010, s149, schedule 19, part 1.)

fields.name: Duty: To share information
fields.details:
NHS England must share information about patients for whom it is responsible with other health and social care organisations involved in their care.  (There are various carve outs.)  Note that this provision does not enable the sharing of data that breaches the Data Protection Act 1998, the common law duty of confidence or the common law duty of care.
(Health and Social Care Act 2012, section 251B)

fields.name: Duty: To consider the economic, social and environmental benefits to be achieved through commissioning
fields.details:
General duty on NHS England to consider the economic, environmental and social benefits that can be achieved through commissioning.
(Public Services (Social Value) Act 2012, S1)

fields.name: Duty: To provide healthy start vitamins
fields.details:
NHS England must arrange for the provision of Healthy Start vitamins if it provides, or arranges for the provision of, maternity services or a child health clinic.
(Healthy Start Scheme and Welfare Foods (Amendment) Regulations 2005, regulation 8A)

fields.name: Power: To enter into section 75 agreements with CCGs, providers and local authorities
fields.details:
NHS England can carry out the “health functions” and “health related functions” of a local authority, CCG NHS Trust, NHS Foundation Trust and vice versa if it enters into an agreement with that organisation that complies with the regulations. These agreements are often called section 75 agreements.

In practice this means that NHS England can carry out the functions of other organisations.

These arrangements can only be made in relation to health functions and health related functions.  These terms are defined in detail in the regulations.  Details of what functions are being carried out by which organisation will be contained in the section 75 agreement itself.

(NHS and Local Authorities Partnership Arrangements Regulations 2000)

fields.name: Power: To enter in to and manage framework agreements for the purchase of services, drugs and medicines
fields.details:
NHS England may conclude and manage framework agreements to facilitate the purchase and supply of a service, drug, medicine or other substance or product that is provided as part of the health service.
(National Health Service Commissioning Board (Additional Functions) Regulations 2017, Regulation 4)

fields.name: Duty: To provide health service for prisoners
fields.details:
NHSCB must arrange, to the extent as it considers necessary to meet all reasonable requirements, provision of services for prisoners and other detainees
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) 2012, Part 3)

fields.name: Duty: To provide community dental services
fields.details:
NHSCB must arrange, to the extent as it considers necessary to meet all reasonable requirements, provision of community dental services
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) 2012, Part 3)

fields.name: Duty: To provide health services to the armed forces
fields.details:
NHSCB must arrange, to the extent as it considers necessary to meet all reasonable requirements, provision of services for serving members of the armed forces and their families
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) 2012, Part 3)

fields.name: Duty: To provide services for rare and very rare conditions
fields.details:
NHSCB must arrange, to the extent as it considers necessary to meet all reasonable requirements, provision of specified service for rare and very conditions; and
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) 2012, Part 3)

fields.name: Duty: To provide mental health after care services
fields.details:
NHS England has a duty to arrange for the provision of mental health after care services if these fall within the services that NHS England must arrange under the NHS Act 2006.
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, Part 4)

fields.name: Duty: Assessment and provisions of NHS continuing healthcare
fields.details:
When it is commissioning services NHS England has a duty to assess whether someone is eligible for a package of care funded by the NHS to meet physical or mental health needs which have arisen as a result of disability, accident or illness.

(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulation 21)

fields.name: Duty: Co-operation with social services regarding the provision of NHS continuing healthcare
fields.details:
NHS England must co-operate with the relevant local authority regarding continue healthcare services to patients.
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulation 22

fields.name: Duty: Arrangement of personal health budgets
fields.details:
NHS England must ensure that it is able to arrange personal health budgets for the delivery of NHS continuing healthcare.
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulation 32B)

fields.name: Duty: To ensure that patients requiring an elective referral are offered a choice of provider
fields.details:
NHS England must ensure that patients for whom it is responsible for commissioning care and who need an elective referral are given a choice of provider.
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulation 39)

fields.name: Duty: To make arrangements to meet waiting times standards
fields.details:
NHS England must make arrangements to meet the waiting times targets.
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulation 45)

fields.name: Duty: To make arrangements to offer an alternative provider
fields.details:
NHS England must offer an alternative provider in some circumstances
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulations 48 and 53.)

fields.name: Duty: To make arrangements for urgent cancer appointments
fields.details:
NHS England must make arrangements to meet the waiting times targets for cancer treatment.
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulation 52)

fields.name: Duty: To ensure buying decisions are fair and improve quality and efficiency of healthcare services
fields.details:
Decisions made by NHS England about the purchase of healthcare services (excluding pharmaceutical services) must be transparent and fair, and improve the quality and efficiency of healthcare services for patients. In particular NHS England must act with a view to:

* (a) Securing the needs of the people who use the services
* (b) Improving the quality of the services
* (c) Improving efficiency in the provisions of the services.

(NHS (Procurement, Patient Choice and Competition) (No.2) Regulations 2013)

fields.name: Duty: To promote individual wellbeing
fields.details:
When carrying out their functions under the Care Act 2014, local authorities must act in a way to promote an individual’s well-being.  Well-being includes physical and mental health, as well as broader factors like participation in work or training.

(Care Act 2014, s1)

fields.name: Power: To provide preventative services
fields.details:
A local authority must provide services that:

* Help prevent or delay the need of adults for care and support
* Help prevent or delay the need of carers for support
* Reduce the need of adults for care and support
* Reduce the needs of carers for support

When doing this, a local authority must have regard to services/ resources already available in its area and consider whether these services/ resource can be used.  This will include any services offered by NHS England and/ or CCGs.

(Care Act 2014, s2)

fields.name: Duty: To carry out functions with the aim of integrating services
fields.details: Local authorities must carry out their care functions with a view "to ensuring the integration of care and support provision with health provision and health-related provision”.  Health-related provision excludes social care services. (Care Act 2014, s3)

fields.name: Duty: To provide information and advice about care and support
fields.details: Local authorities must establish and maintain a service for providing people in its area with information and advice relating to care and support for adults and support for carers. (Care Act 2014, s4)

fields.name: Duty: To meet the care and support needs of eligible adults
fields.details:
In certain circumstances, a local authority must meet the care and support needs of individuals meeting the eligibility criteria.

This cannot include providing services that the NHS is required to deliver unless:

* doing so is ancillary to other services that are being provided; and
* the service of a nature that the local authority could be expected to provide.

(Care Act 2014, s18)

fields.name: Power: To meet the care and support needs of eligible adults
fields.details:
In certain circumstances, a local authority has discretion as to whether it meets the care and support needs of individuals meeting the eligibility criteria if the section 18 duty does not apply.

This cannot include providing services that the NHS is required to deliver unless:

* doing so is ancillary to other services that are being provided; and
* the service of a nature that the local authority could be expected to provide.

(Care Act 2014, s19)

fields.name: Duty: To meet the support needs of eligible carers
fields.details:
In certain circumstances, a local authority must meet the support needs of carers meeting the eligibility criteria.

This cannot include providing services that the NHS is required to deliver unless:

* doing so is ancillary to other services that are being provided; and
* the service of a nature that the local authority could be expected to provide.

(Care Act 2014, s20)

fields.name: Power: To meet the support needs of eligible carers
fields.details:
In certain circumstances, a local authority has discretion as to whether it meets the support needs of individuals meeting the eligibility criteria if the section 20 duty does not apply.

This cannot include providing services that the NHS is required to deliver unless:

* doing so is ancillary to other services that are being provided; and
* the service of a nature that the local authority could be expected to provide.

(Care Act 2014, s20)

fields.name: Power: To delegate some care functions under the Care Act 2014
fields.details:
Local authorities can delegate:
* their care and support functions under the Care Act 2014
* after care duties under section 117 of the Mental Health Act 1983

However, this does not include duties to promote integration and co-operate with other bodies, safeguarding and charging.  These cannot be delegated.

(Care Act 2014, s79)

fields.name: Duty: To make direct payments to meet care needs
fields.details:
In some circumstances, local authorities must make direct payments to meet care needs.  Such needs can include after-care under the Mental Health Act 1983.  Detail is set out in regulations.
(Care Act 2014, sections 31, 32 and 33, Schedule 4
Care and Support (Direct Payments) Regulations 2014)

fields.name: Duty: To improve the well-being of and reduce inequalities for children
fields.details: A local authority must improve the well-being of and reduce inequalities between children in its area, including health inequalities. (Childcare Act 2006, s1)

fields.name: Duty: To co-operate with NHS England and CCGs when assessing the risks posed by offenders
fields.details:
Local authorities must make arrangements for managing the risks posed by some offenders.  In doing so they must co-operate with NHS England and CCGs.
(Criminal Justice Act 2003, section 325)

fields.name: Duty: To assess certain patients for eligibility for welfare provision
fields.details:
Local authorities must make arrangements to assess people who have been an in-patient for one period of at least six months for treatment of a mental disorder to assess whether they are eligible for welfare services.  They must co-operate with any CCG that is also carrying out an assessment.
(Disabled Persons (Services, Consultation and Representation) Act 1986, s7)

fields.name: Duties: To deliver education services (various)
fields.details: Local authorities are subject to various duties under different legislation to provide education services. (Education Act 1996, section 578)

fields.name: Power: To delegate to Health & Wellbeing Board
fields.details:
A local authority may arrange for a Health and Wellbeing Board established by it to exercise any functions that are usually carried out by the authority.  This does not apply to review and scrutiny functions.

(Health and Social Care Act 2012, section 196)

fields.name: Power: To supply/ receive goods and services
fields.details:
Local authorities may supply CCGs and NHS England with:

* goods or materials
* administrative, professional or technical services 
* vehicles, plant or other apparatus, including associated staff.

This does not permit local authorities to construct any buildings

(Local Authorities (Goods and Services) Act 1970, section 1)

fields.name: Duties: Social care (various)
fields.details:
Local authorities are subject to various duties under different legislation to provide social care services.

(Local Authority Social Services Act 1970, Schedule 1)

fields.name: Duty: To prepare a joint strategic needs assessment
fields.details: Local authorities must prepare a joint strategic needs assessment with the relevant local authority and a joint health and wellbeing strategy to meet those needs. (Local Government and Public Involvement in Health Act 2007, section 116 & 116A)

fields.name: Duty: To ensure the involvement of local people in decision-making
fields.details:
Local authorities must make contractual arrangements to:

* enable the involvement of local people in the commissioning, provision and scrutiny of local health and social care services
* obtain the views of local people about their need for and experience of local health and social care services.

(Local Government and Public Involvement in Health Act 2007, s221)

fields.name: Power: To provide recreational facilities
fields.details: Local authorities may provide recreational facilities, for example sports centres, swimming pools, tennis courts, outdoor sports pitches.  This can include the provision of staff and facilities connected with any recreational facilities, like parking spaces and refreshment facilities. (Local Government (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1976, s19)

fields.name: Power: General Power
fields.details:
Local authorities can generally do anything that an individual can do, subject to any limitations that:

* were in place before the Localism Act 2011 came into force; or
* were put in place after the Localism Act was passed and are expressly said to apply.

There are some other restrictions.

This power is intended to be very broad.  It can cover doing things for a commercial purpose i.e. to generate income and charging for services.

(Localism Act 2011, s1-4)

fields.name: Duty: Providing after care of patients with mental health problems
fields.details:
Local authorities must, together with the CCG and relevant voluntary agencies, arrange for the provision of after care for persons previously detained under the Mental Health Act, at the time that they cease to be detained. Such after care should be provided until the local social services authority is satisfied that such services are no longer required.

(Mental Health Act 1983, s117)

fields.name: Duty: To make arrangements for independent mental health advocates
fields.details: Local authorities must make reasonable arrangements to make sure that independent mental health advocates are available to help certain types of patient. (Mental Health Act 1983, section 130A)

fields.name: Duty: To exercise any functions delegated to the local authority by the Secretary of State
fields.details:
The Secretary of State duties under the NHS Act 2006 can in some circumstances be delegated to local authorities and combined authorities.

(NHS Act 2006, section 13ZA)
Regulations 2012

fields.name: Duty: To make services available to NHS bodies
fields.details: Each local authority must make services available to NHS England and CCGs acting in its area to help them discharge their functions under the NHS Act 2006.  However, a local authority only has to do what is reasonable and practicable. (NHS Act 2006, section 74(3))

fields.name: Power: To enter into section 75 agreements with NHS England or local authorities
fields.details: Local authorities can enter into section 75 agreements with CCGs and/ or NHS England for the delivery of health services and health-related services.  This means that local authorities can carry out some of the functions of CCGs and/or NHS England and vice versa. (NHS Act 2006, s75, NHS Bodies and Local Authorities Partnership Agreements 2000)

fields.name: Power: To make payments to CCGs and NHS England
fields.details:
Local authorities can make payments to CCGs and/or NHS England, provided this is for one of the purposes set out in regulations.  

(NHS Act 2006, section 76, NHS Bodies and Local Authorities (Partnership Arrangements, Care Trusts, Public Health and Local Healthwatch) , Regulation 13)

fields.name: Duty: To co-operate with CCGs and NHS England
fields.details: Local authorities have a duty to cooperate with CCGs and NHS England. (NHS Act 2006, section 82)

fields.name: Power: To provide premises, furniture or equipment
fields.details: Local authorities responsible for delivering social care services can provide premises, furniture or equipment to a CCG or NHS England for any of the purposes of the NHS Act 2006.  These purposes include the provision of NHS services and the promotion of public health. (NHS Act 2006, s254)

fields.name: Duty (nhs trust only): Provision of NHS goods and services
fields.details: NHS Trusts provide goods and services for the purposes of the NHS. (NHS Act 2006, s25)

fields.name: Duty (nhs trust only): Delivery of services set out in Establishment Order (various)
fields.details:
NHS Trusts must deliver the services set out in their Establishment Order.  This will usually refer to the locations at which the Trust is to deliver NHS Services.  It may also include reference to teaching and research facilities

(NHS Act 2006, section 25, Various Establishment Orders – there is one for each NHS Trust)

fields.name: Duty (nhs trust only): Efficient delivery of functions
fields.details: An NHS Trust must exercise its functions effectively, efficiently and economically. (NHS Act 2006, s26)

fields.name: Duty (nhs ft only): Delivery of NHS goods and services
fields.details: The principal purpose of an NHS Foundation Trust is to  provide goods and services for the purposes of the NHS in England   (NHS Act 2006, s43(1))

fields.name: Power (nhs ft only): Provision of  goods/ services related to healthcare or public health
fields.details:
An NHS Foundation Trust may provide goods and services for any purposes related to:

* the provision of services to individuals for or in connection with the prevention, diagnosis or treatment of illness
* the promotion and protection of public health

(NHS Act 2006, s43(2))

fields.name: Power (nhs ft only): Income generation
fields.details: An NHS Foundation Trust can carry on additional activities to generate additional income that helps it better deliver NHS care. (NHS Act 2006, s43(3))

fields.name: Power (nhs ft only): To charge for accommodation or extra services
fields.details: An NHS Foundation Trust may charge patients for accommodation or non-NHS services. (NHS Act 2006, s44)

fields.name: Power (nhs ft only): General Power
fields.details: An NHS Foundation Trust can do anything that appears to it to be necessary or expedient for the purpose of or in connection with its functions. (NHS Act 2006, s47)

fields.name: Duty (nhs ft only): Efficient exercise of functions
fields.details: An NHS Foundation Trust must exercise its functions effectively, efficiently and economically. (NHS Act 2006, s63)

fields.name: Duty: NHS bodies to co-operate
fields.details: Duty for NHS bodies to co-operate with each other in exercising their functions  (NHS Act 2006, s72)

fields.name: Power (nhs trust only): General Power
fields.details: An NHS Trust can do anything that appears to it to be necessary or expedient for the purpose of or in connection with its functions. (NHS Act 2006, Schedule 4, paragraph 14)

fields.name: Power (nhs trust only): Research
fields.details: An NHS Trust can undertake and commission research.  It can also make staff and facilities available to other people or organisations carrying out research. (NHS Act 2006, Schedule 4, paragraph 16)

fields.name: Power (nhs trust only): Joint exercise of functions
fields.details: An NHS Trust can arrange to carry out its functions jointly with any other organisation. (NHS Act 2006, Schedule 4, paragraph 18)

fields.name: Power (nhs trust only): Charges for accommodation or extra services
fields.details: An NHS Trust may charge patients for accommodation or non-NHS services provided this does not interfere with NHS services.  In some cases approval is needed from the Department of Health. (NHS Act 2006, Schedule 4, paragraph 19)

fields.name: Power (nhs trust only): Income generation
Duty: Public involvement
fields.details:
NHS Trusts and Foundation Trusts must make arrangements for involving the public and patients in:

* the planning of services
* the development of proposals for changes in the way those services are provided
* decisions about the operations of those services

(NHS Act 2006, s242)

fields.name: Power: Be partnership organisations
fields.details: Ability for NHS Trusts and Foundation Trusts to second/ offer the services of Trust/ Foundation Trust staff to local authorities and vice versa. (Local Government Act 1972 s113 (1A))

fields.name: Duty: To commission hospital accommodation, medical, ophthalmic, nursing and ambulance service
fields.details:
A  CCG must arrange for the provision of health services to meet the reasonable requirements of the persons for whom it has responsibility. These health services include:

* hospital accommodation
* any other accommodation needed for the delivery of services under the NHS Act 2006
* medical, ophthalmic, nursing and ambulance services.
* services for the care of pregnant women, women who are breastfeeding and young children 
* other services or facilities for the prevention of illness, the care of persons suffering from illness and the after-care of persons who have suffered from illness 
* other services needed for the diagnosis and treatment of illness

If there is overlap between this duty on CCGs and any duty on NHS England to provide services, then the CCG duty will not apply. 

(NHS Act 2006, section 3)

fields.name: Power: To commission certain other health services
fields.details:
Each CCG provide the healthcare services that it considers appropriate for the purposes of the health service that relate to securing improvement in –
(a) the physical and mental health of persons for whom it has responsibility; or
(b) the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of illness in those persons.
These services cannot include high security psychiatric services that NHS England has to deliver, or any services that the Secretary of State has ordered NHS England to deliver.

(NHS Act 2006, section 3A)

fields.name: Power: Arrange of performance of functions outside England
fields.details:
A CCG can arrange for services to be provided outside of England if this relates to:

* holidays for patients
* the transfer of patients to or from Scotland, Northern Ireland, the Isle of Man or the Channel Islands, or    
* the return of patients who have received treatment in England and Wales, to countries or territories outside the British Islands (including for this purpose the Republic of Ireland).

(NHS Act 2006 s6 (1A))

fields.name: Power: To assist Secretary of State in providing health services and exercising public health functions
fields.details:
The Secretary of State for Health can require a CCG to carry out some of his public health tasks.  

(NHS Act 2006, section 7A)

fields.name: Duty: To exercise any functions delegated to the CCG by the Secretary of State
fields.details: The Secretary of State duties under the NHS Act 2006 can be delegated to CCGs. (NHS Act 2006, section 13Z)

fields.name: Duty: Exercise its functions efficiently
fields.details: Duty to exercise its functions effectively, efficiently and economically.  (NHS Act 2006, s14Q)

fields.name: Duty: Securing continuous improvement in quality of services provided to individuals
fields.details: Duty on CCGs to exercise their functions with a view to securing continuous improvement in the quality of health services provided to individuals  (NHS Act 2006, s14R)

fields.name: Duty: Improving quality of primary medical services
fields.details: Duty to support NHS England to deliver NHS England’s duty secure continuous improvement in the quality of primary medical services. (NHS Act 2006, s14S HSCA 2012 s26)

fields.name: Duty: Reduce health inequalities
fields.details:
When carrying out their functions CCGs must have regard to the need to:

* reduce inequalities in relation to accessing health services
* reduce inequalities between patients that relate to the provision of healthcare services 

(NHS Act 2006, s14T)

fields.name: Duty: To promote the involvement of each patient
fields.details:
CCGs must promote the involvement of patients, and their carers and representatives (if any), in decisions which relate to:

* the prevention or diagnosis of illness in the patients, or
* their care or treatment.

(NHS Act 2006, section 14U)

fields.name: Duty: Research
fields.details: CCGs must promote research relevant to the health service and the use of such research in the health service. (NHS Act 2006, s14Y)

fields.name: Duty: to promote integrated health services
fields.details:
CCGs have a duty to exercise their functions with a view to ensuring that health services are provided in an integrated way where this would:

* improve quality of health services (including outcomes) or
* reduce inequalities of access to health services or
* reduce inequalities of outcomes achieved by health services

(NHS Act 2006, section 14Z1(1))

fields.name: Duty: to promote integration between health services and health-related services
fields.details:
CCGs have a duty to exercise their functions with a view to ensuring that health services are integrated with the provision of health-related services and social care services where this would: 

* improve quality of health services (including outcomes) or
* reduce inequalities of access to health services or
* reduce inequalities of outcomes achieved by health services

“Health-related services” includes any service that has an effect on the health of individuals but that is not a health or social care service e.g. housing.

(NHS Act 2006, s14Z(2))

fields.name: Power: For a CCG to deliver services jointly with another CCG
fields.details: CCGs can exercise their functions jointly, or on behalf of one another.  This means that one CCG can take on the functions of another. (NHS Act 2006, section 14Z3)

fields.name: Power: For a CCG to deliver services jointly with a combined authority
fields.details: CCGs can exercise their functions jointly with a combined authority.  (A combined authority is type of group of local authorities.) (NHS Act 2006, s14Z3A)

fields.name: Power: For a CCG to deliver services jointly with a Local Health Board
fields.details: CCGs can exercise their functions jointly with Local Health Boards.  (A Local Health Board is a public sector organisation in Wales that commissions healthcare services.) (NHS Act 2006, section 14Z4)

fields.name: Power: For NHS England to deliver CCG services instead of or jointly with a CCG
fields.details: CCGs can deliver their functions jointly with NHS England, or NHS England can deliver the functions on behalf of the CCG (NHS Act 2006, s14Z9)

fields.name: Duty: Payments to providers to NHS England specification
fields.details: Duty to be adhere to any NHS England document published under section 14Z7 (payments to providers). (NHS Act 2006 s14Z7, HSCA s26)

fields.name: Power: To enter into section 75 agreements with NHSE, CCGs, providers and local authorities
fields.details:
CCGs can enter into section 75 agreements with local authorities for the delivery of health services and health-related services.  This means that local authorities can carry out some of the functions of CCGs and vice versa.

(NHS Act 2006, section 75
NHS Bodies and Local Authorities Partnership Agreements 2000)

fields.name: Duty: To make CCG facilities available to local authorities
fields.details:
CCGs must make available to local authorities any services or facilities the provision of which is arranged by the CCG, the services of persons employed by the CCG, and any facilities of the CCG, so far as is reasonably necessary to enable local authorities to discharge their functions relating to social services, education and public health.

(NHS Act 2006, section 80(6A))

fields.name: Duty: To comply with Better Care Fund conditions
fields.details: CCGs must comply with any conditions attached to Better Care Funding. (NHS Act 2006, section 223GA)

fields.name: Duty: To not go in to deficit
fields.details: Each CCG has a duty to perform its functions for each financial year so as to ensure that its expenditure does not exceed its income for that year. (NHS Act 2006, s223H)

fields.name: Duty: Take appropriate steps in an emergency
fields.details: Each CCG must take appropriate steps to secure that it is properly prepared for dealing with relevant emergencies. (NHS Act 2006 s252A and HSCA s46)

fields.name: Power: Provision of wheelchairs and vehicles
fields.details: A CCG may provide vehicles (including wheelchairs) to people who have a physical impairment that has a substantial and long-term adverse effect on their ability to carry out normal day-to-day activities. (NHS Act 2006 Schedule 1, paragraph 9)

fields.name: Duty: To co-operate with local authorities
fields.details: CCGs have a duty to cooperate with local authorities. (NHS Act 2006, s82)

fields.name: Duty: To work with local authorities regarding adoption services
fields.details: CCGs have a duty to work with local authorities in respect of the need to maintain adoption services via the provision of facilities for this purpose (Adoption and Children Act 2002, s4)

fields.name: Duty: To reduce drug and alcohol abuse
fields.details: CCGs have a duty to work in co-operation with the police to formulate and implement a strategy to reduce the use of drugs, alcohol and other substances reduce reoffending and reduce crime and disorder (Crime and Disorder Act 1998, section 5)

fields.name: Duty: To make arrangements for needs assessments for services after discharge
fields.details:
CCGs must make arrangements for an assessment of the needs of a long-term in-patients who have been receiving medical treatment for mental disorder, to inform the provision of services in relation to the discharge of a patient from hospital

(Disabled Persons (Services, Consultation and Representation) Act 1986, s7)

fields.name: Duty: To help local authorities deliver special educational needs services
fields.details: CCGs have a duty to assist a local authority in the discharge of its special educational needs functions at the request of the local authority. (Education Act 1996, s322)

fields.name: Power: To partner with local authorities
fields.details: CCGs have the power to be partnership organisations of local authorities and are able to receive the services of local authorities officers  (Local Government Act 1972, section 113(1A))

fields.name: Duty: After care of patients with mental health problems
fields.details:
CCGs must, together with the local authority and relevant voluntary agencies, arrange for the provision of after care for people previously detained under the Mental Health Act, at the time that they cease to be detained. Such after care should be provided until the local social services authority is satisfied that such services are no longer required.
(Mental Health Act 1983 s117)

fields.name: Duty: To comply with NICE technology appraisal recommendations
fields.details: CCGs must comply with a technology appraisal recommendation made by the National Institute for Health & Care Excellence (National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (Constitution and Functions) and the Health and Social Care Information Centre (Functions) Regulations 2013)

fields.name: Duty: Assessment and provision of NHS continuing healthcare
fields.details: When it is commissioning services a CCG has a duty to assess whether someone is eligible for a package of care funded by the NHS to meet physical or mental health needs which have arisen as a result of disability, accident or illness; (NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulation 21)

fields.name: Power: Process data for legitmate interest
Duty: Provide services to improve public health
Power: To assist the Department of Health in providing health services and exercising public health functions
Duty: To assist the Department of Health in providing health services and exercising public health functions
Duty: To scrutinise local healthcare arrangements
Provider duty: To ensure the involvement of local people in decision-making
Provider power: To provide preventative services
Provider duty: To provide information and advice about care and support
Provider duty: To provide open access sexual health services
Provider duty: To make direct payments to meet care needs
Provider power: To make direct payments to patients
Provider duties: To deliver education services (various)
Provider duty: To provide information and advice to promote the preparation of health protection arrangements
Provider duty: To provide for the medical inspection and treatment of pupils at local authority schools
Provider duty: To provide health checks for eligible people
Commissioner power: To provide preventative services
Commissioner duty: To provide a public health advice service
Commissioner duty: To make direct payments to meet care needs
Commissioner power: To make direct payments to patients
Commissioner duty: To ensure the involvement of local people in decision-making
Commissioner duty: To prepare a joint strategic needs assessment
Commissioner duty: To consider the economic, social and environmental benefits to be achieved through commissioning
Commissioner duty: To provide information and advice to promote the preparation of health protection arrangements
Commissioner duty: Provide services to improve public health
Providing public health population healthcare advice
Specialised and highly specialised services
fields.additional_information: NHS England is responsible for commissioning £15.6 billion of specialised services to meet a wide range of health and care needs. These include a range of services from renal dialysis and secure inpatient mental health services, through to treatments for rare cancers and life threatening genetic disorders. The commissioning of specialised services is a prescribed direct commissioning responsibility of NHS England.

fields.name: Primary care
fields.additional_information: NHS England is responsible for commissioning primary care services, including primary medical care, pharmaceutical services, ophthalmic services and dental services.

fields.name: Public health s7a
fields.additional_information: The NHS has a critical part to play in securing good population health. The public health functions agreement (S7A) is an annual agreement between the Secretary of State for Health and NHS England. These services include services from pregnancy to age 5, immunisations and national screening.

fields.name: Health and justice
fields.additional_information: Section 15 of the Health and Social Care Act 2012 gave the Secretary of State the power to require NHS England to commission services or facilities for persons who are detained in a prison or in other accommodation of a prescribed description. This responsibility also includes commissioning Sexual Assault Referral services.

fields.name: Armed forces
fields.additional_information: Section 15 of the Health and Social Care Act 2012, gives the Secretary of State the power to require NHS England to commission services or facilities for members of the Armed Forces or their families.

fields.name: Secondary dental
fields.additional_information: NHS England is responsible for commissioning secondary dental services.

fields.name: Assurance of CCG-commissioned services
fields.additional_information: Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs) were established on 1 April 2013 and are clinically-led organisations at the heart of the NHS system.

fields.name: Assurance of major service changes and redesigns
fields.additional_information: NHS England’s role in reconfiguration is to support commissioners and their local partners to develop clear, evidence based proposals for service reconfiguration, and to undertake assurance as mandated by the Government.

fields.name: Development of health and care policy and financial allocations
fields.additional_information: NHS England leads the National Health Service (NHS) in England. It sets the priorities and direction of the NHS and encourage and inform the national debate to improve health and care.

fields.name: Urgent and emergency care
fields.additional_information: Includes Urgent and emergency care (including 111, A&E and ambulance services) for anyone present in a CCGs geographic area and out-of-hours primary medical services (for everyone present in your area), except where this responsibility has been retained by practices under the GP contract

fields.name: Elective care
fields.additional_information: Covers elective hospital care

fields.name: Community care
fields.additional_information: Includes speech and language therapy, continence services, wheelchair services, and home oxygen services, but not public health services such as health visiting and family nursing

fields.name: GP with special interests activity
fields.additional_information: Covers other community-based services, including (where appropriate) services provided by GP practices that go beyond the scope of the GP contract

fields.name: Rehabilitation
fields.additional_information: Rehabilitation services

fields.name: Maternity and new-born
fields.additional_information: Excludes neonatal intensive care

fields.name: Children's healthcare
fields.additional_information: Covers children's mental and physical health

fields.name: NHS continuing healthcare
fields.additional_information: NHS Continuing Healthcare

fields.name: Infertility
fields.additional_information: Infertility Services

fields.name: Mental health and learning disabilities
fields.additional_information: Includes mental health services, psychological therapies and services for people with learning disabilities

fields.name: Primary care
fields.additional_information: CCGs have a responsibility to support systems improvements in local primary care services, including primary medical care, pharmaceutical services, ophthalmic services and dental services.

fields.name: Children's public health
fields.additional_information: Healthy child programme for school-age children (aged 5-19), including school nursing

fields.name: Sexual health
fields.additional_information: Including contraception over and above GP contract, testing and treatment of sexually transmitted infections (excluding HIV treatment), sexual health advice, prevention and promotion

fields.name: Public mental health
fields.additional_information: Including mental health promotion, mental illness prevention and suicide prevention

fields.name: Physical activity and obesity management
fields.additional_information: Local programmes to address inactivity and other interventions to promote physical activity, local programmes to prevent and address obesity, e.g. National Child Measurement Programme and weight management services

fields.name: Substance misuse
fields.additional_information: Drug and alcohol misuse services, prevention and treatment, local tobacco activity, including stop smoking services, prevention activity, enforcement and communications

fields.name: Dental public health
fields.additional_information: Including epidemiology, dental screening and oral health improvement, including water fluoridation (subject to consultation)

fields.name: Other local authority public health services
fields.additional_information: Including nutrition, NHS Health Check programme, reducing and preventing birth defects, health at work, accidental injury prevention, seasonal mortality, public health and justice, infectious diseases, health protection

fields.name: Children's public health
fields.additional_information: Healthy child programme for school-age children (aged 5-19), including school nursing

fields.name: Sexual health
fields.additional_information: Including contraception over and above GP contract, testing and treatment of sexually transmitted infections (excluding HIV treatment), sexual health advice, prevention and promotion

fields.name: Public mental health
fields.additional_information: Including mental health promotion, mental illness prevention and suicide prevention

fields.name: Physical activity and obesity management
fields.additional_information: Local programmes to address inactivity and other interventions to promote physical activity, local programmes to prevent and address obesity, e.g. National Child Measurement Programme and weight management services

fields.name: Substance misuse
fields.additional_information: Drug and alcohol misuse services, prevention and treatment, local tobacco activity, including stop smoking services, prevention activity, enforcement and communications

fields.name: Dental public health
fields.additional_information: Including epidemiology, dental screening and oral health improvement, including water fluoridation (subject to consultation)

fields.name: Other local authority public health services
fields.additional_information: Including nutrition, NHS Health Check programme, reducing and preventing birth defects, health at work, accidental injury prevention, seasonal mortality, public health and justice, infectious diseases, health protection

fields.name: Core offer
fields.additional_information: Local authorities, as part of their statutory functions around public health, will have responsibility for providing healthcare public health advice to clinical commissioning groups (CCGs)

fields.name: Adults' social care
fields.additional_information: TBC

fields.name: Children's social care
fields.additional_information: TBC

fields.name: Care homes
fields.additional_information: TBC

fields.name: Mental health aftercare
fields.additional_information: TBC

fields.name: Adults' social care
fields.additional_information: TBC

fields.name: Children's social care
fields.additional_information: TBC

fields.name: Care homes
fields.additional_information: TBC

fields.name: Mental health aftercare
fields.additional_information: TBC

fields.name: Urgent and emergency care
fields.additional_information: Includes Urgent and emergency care (including 111, A&E and ambulance services) for anyone present in a CCGs geographic area and out-of-hours primary medical services (for everyone present in your area), except where this responsibility has been retained by practices under the GP contract

fields.name: Elective care
fields.additional_information: Covers elective hospital care

fields.name: Community care
fields.additional_information: Includes rehabilitation services, speech and language therapy, continence services, wheelchair services, and home oxygen services, but not public health services such as health visiting and family nursing

fields.name: GP with special interests activity
fields.additional_information: Covers other community-based services, including (where appropriate) services provided by GP practices that go beyond the scope of the GP contract

fields.name: Rehabilitation
fields.additional_information: Rehabilitation services

fields.name: Maternity and new-born
fields.additional_information: Excludes neonatal intensive care

fields.name: Children's healthcare
fields.additional_information: Covers children's mental and physical health

fields.name: NHS Continuing healthcare
fields.additional_information: NHS Continuing Healthcare

fields.name: Infertility
fields.additional_information: Infertility Services

fields.name: Mental health and learning disabilities
fields.additional_information: Includes mental health services, psychological therapies and services for people with learning disabilities

fields.name: Specialised and highly specialised services
fields.additional_information: NHS England is responsible for commissioning £15.6 billion of specialised services to meet a wide range of health and care needs. These include a range of services from renal dialysis and secure inpatient mental health services, through to treatments for rare cancers and life threatening genetic disorders. The commissioning of specialised services is a prescribed direct commissioning responsibility of NHS England.

fields.name: Primary care
fields.additional_information: NHS England is responsible for commissioning primary care services, including primary medical care, pharmaceutical services, ophthalmic services and dental services.

fields.name: Public health s7a
fields.additional_information: The NHS has a critical part to play in securing good population health. The public health functions agreement (S7A) is an annual agreement between the Secretary of State for Health and NHS England. These services include services from pregnancy to age 5, immunisations and national screening.

fields.name: Health and justice
fields.additional_information: Section 15 of the Health and Social Care Act 2012 gave the Secretary of State the power to require NHS England to commission services or facilities for persons who are detained in a prison or in other accommodation of a prescribed description. This responsibility also includes commissioning Sexual Assault Referral services.

fields.name: Armed forces
fields.additional_information: Section 15 of the Health and Social Care Act 2012, gives the Secretary of State the power to require NHS England to commission services or facilities for members of the Armed Forces or their families.

fields.name: Secondary dental
fields.additional_information: NHS England is responsible for commissioning secondary dental services.

fields.name: Urgent and emergency care
fields.additional_information: Includes Urgent and emergency care (including 111, A&E and ambulance services) for anyone present in a CCGs geographic area and out-of-hours primary medical services (for everyone present in your area), except where this responsibility has been retained by practices under the GP contract

fields.name: Elective care
fields.additional_information: Covers elective hospital care

fields.name: Community care
fields.additional_information: Includes rehabilitation services, speech and language therapy, continence services, wheelchair services, and home oxygen services, but not public health services such as health visiting and family nursing

fields.name: GP with special interests activity
fields.additional_information: Covers other community-based services, including (where appropriate) services provided by GP practices that go beyond the scope of the GP contract

fields.name: Rehabilitation
fields.additional_information: Rehabilitation services

fields.name: Maternity and new-born
fields.additional_information: Excludes neonatal intensive care

fields.name: Children's healthcare
fields.additional_information: Covers children's mental and physical health

fields.name: NHS Continuing healthcare
fields.additional_information: NHS Continuing Healthcare

fields.name: Infertility
fields.additional_information: Infertility Services

fields.name: Mental health and learning disabilities
fields.additional_information: Includes mental health services, psychological therapies and services for people with learning disabilities

fields.name: Specialised and highly specialised services
fields.additional_information: NHS England is responsible for commissioning £15.6 billion of specialised services to meet a wide range of health and care needs. These include a range of services from renal dialysis and secure inpatient mental health services, through to treatments for rare cancers and life threatening genetic disorders. The commissioning of specialised services is a prescribed direct commissioning responsibility of NHS England.

fields.name: Primary care
fields.additional_information: NHS England is responsible for commissioning primary care services, including primary medical care, pharmaceutical services, ophthalmic services and dental services.

fields.name: Public health s7a
fields.additional_information: The NHS has a critical part to play in securing good population health. The public health functions agreement (S7A) is an annual agreement between the Secretary of State for Health and NHS England. These services include services from pregnancy to age 5, immunisations and national screening.

fields.name: Health and justice
fields.additional_information: Section 15 of the Health and Social Care Act 2012 gave the Secretary of State the power to require NHS England to commission services or facilities for persons who are detained in a prison or in other accommodation of a prescribed description. This responsibility also includes commissioning Sexual Assault Referral services.

fields.name: Armed forces
fields.additional_information: Section 15 of the Health and Social Care Act 2012, gives the Secretary of State the power to require NHS England to commission services or facilities for members of the Armed Forces or their families.

fields.name: Secondary dental
fields.additional_information: NHS England is responsible for commissioning secondary dental services.

fields.name: Tabulation
fields.description:
A data table is a simple output of raw data, often to be consumed for a downstream purpose.

For this description to apply, the data table(s) must only contain data that has been aggregated and is fully anonymised in line with the ICO's Anonymisation Code of Practice.

fields.name: Visualisation
fields.description: Data visualisation helps users, often non-analytical, to understand data and evidence. A primary goal of data visualization is to communicate information clearly and efficiently to users via the statistical graphics, plots, information graphics, tables, and charts selected. Visualisations, in this context, also include dashboards as visualisation tools that display the current status of metrics and key performance indicators (KPIs).

fields.name: Report
fields.description:
A report is a written account of something that has been undertaken, observed or investigated. Reports can take a variety of forms (paper, presentation etc.) and be produced for a wide range of audiences (publication, management, Board reports etc.). They will usually contain summary information and conclusions and should not contain raw patient-level data.

Routine reports are produced at agreed regular intervals to provide ongoing assurance to customers, management and stakeholders about the performance of outcomes, projects and business functions.

fields.name: Tabulation
fields.description:
A data table is a simple output of raw data, often to be consumed for a downstream purpose.

For this description to apply, the data table(s) will contain at least one data record that refers to a single individual, however all identifiable attributes have been effectively de-identified in line with the ICO's Anonymisation Code of Practice.

fields.name: Tabulation
fields.description:
A data table is a simple output of raw data, often to be consumed for a downstream purpose.

For this description to apply, the data table(s) will contain at least one data record that refers to a single individual where one or more identifiable attributes remain in the data in raw form.

fields.name: Community and out of hospital care
